title: Figma Unveils AI-Powered Erase, Isolate, and Expand Tools for Seamless In-Canvas Image Editing

paragraphs.content: Figma launched three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—on December 10, 2025, enabling precise edits directly on the canvas without exporting to apps like Photoshop.These features consolidate with existing tools like Remove background and Crop in a revamped toolbar, available in Figma Design and Draw for Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans with AI enabled.The tools use an improved lasso selector for granular control, addressing common pain points in adapting images for marketing assets or mockups.

sections.title: Breakdown of Erase Object, Isolate Object, and Expand Image Capabilities

paragraphs.content: **Erase object** lets users select and remove unwanted elements from images using the enhanced lasso tool, preserving surrounding textures and lighting for natural results.**Isolate object** separates a subject from its background, allowing repositioning or effects like blur, desaturation, shadow, color adjustments, or focus while maintaining original image characteristics.These prompt-free AI features streamline tasks like background cleanups in UI mockups or campaign visuals.

paragraphs.content: **Expand image** extends backgrounds to new aspect ratios without distortion, ideal for converting square product shots into landscape banners for web or social media.Figma's blog notes these tools join AI image generation to "close the loop on workflows," keeping edits in-context.The centralized toolbar prioritizes frequent actions like background removal for faster access.

sections.title: Industry Reactions to Figma's Late but Practical AI Editing Push

paragraphs.content: TechCrunch reports Figma is "finally catching up" to Adobe and Canva, which offered object removal years ago, but praises the in-app convenience for granular, text-prompt-free edits.ContentGrip emphasizes benefits for marketers, noting Erase and Isolate reduce design team dependencies for cleanups and enable faster test variations.Analysts highlight how the tools cut back-and-forth in cross-functional reviews by enabling on-the-fly optimizations.

Figma plans to expand these tools across more products in 2026, building on 150+ features from 2025.Release notes frame the update as centralizing AI editing in a contextual toolbar for enhanced productivity.Coverage positions this as a shift toward AI-native platforms, minimizing multi-app chaos for collaborative teams.
